image.altText: A woman embracing outside of court

props.synopsis: Andrew Thomas Hayler, 38, is sentenced to nine years in jail for uploading digitally altered images of dozens of women he knew, alongside identifying details, to a pornography website.

title.children: 'He deserves it': Sydney man jailed for uploading altered photos of his friends to porn site

image.altText: Coles and Woolworths branding outside neighbouring supermarkets

props.synopsis: The results of comparing identical groceries at different supermarkets were hardly surprising to anyone who has set foot in one in the past 18 months. How many more same-same-but-different reports will tell us what we already know?

title.children: If supermarket reports alone provided cost-of-living relief, groceries would already be cheaper at the check-out

image.altText: A packet of cigarettes on display with bundles of cash as part of a police press conference.

props.synopsis: Police have arrested 13 people — some with alleged links to a Middle Eastern crime group — over the cigarette war that's led to the fire bombings of dozens of tobacco stores across Australia.

title.children: Thirteen people arrested, millions of illicit cigarettes seized in operation targeting illegal tobacco trade

image.altText: Angela Villella weras a green scarf and black and white check coat and holds a coffee cup looking out over the railway station.

props.synopsis: Reservoir residents say the government has ignored their concerns about noise and loss of privacy as trains, commuters now metres from their bedroom windows.

title.children: Residents berate Victorian minister as level crossing removal brings trains within metres of homes

image.altText: Two women stand in front of a brick building with a sign overhead that reads One Red Tree Resource Centre.

props.synopsis: Two friends — a clinical psychologist and a school principal — saw an urgent need for embedded mental health support in a western Victorian community after a string of suicides. Now they're running a not-for-profit that places trainee psychologists in rural schools.

title.children: After seven suicides rocked a regional Victorian town, two women decided to make a difference

image.altText: Rows of Australian hundred dollar bills.

props.synopsis: A 41-year-old man from Melbourne's west has been arrested as part of an investigation into more than 500 allegedly fraudulent applications for COVID-19 payments during the pandemic.

title.children: Police to charge Melbourne man with fraud after 500 COVID isolation payment claims made during pandemic

image.altText: A dirt road barred by high vis markers and a sign saying 'closed'

props.synopsis: A crime scene has been established in Gellibrand Lower after the bodies of a man and a woman were found on a walking track near Wreck Beach.

title.children: Man and woman found dead on walking track near Victoria's Great Ocean Road, police say

image.altText: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese Blue Room

props.synopsis: The prime minister tells an ABC host five times to "lighten up" when asked if Labor's memes mocking the Coalition's nuclear plan were juvenile.

title.children: Albanese tells critics of Labor's three-eyed nuclear memes to 'lighten up'

image.altText: An aerial view of Ashley Youth Detention Centre.

props.synopsis: Tasmanians who were abused as children in the notorious Ashley youth detention centre reach an in-principle agreement to settle their class action with the state government.

title.children: Former detainees abused at Tasmania's Ashley youth detention centre reach $75m deal

image.altText: Sheep in pens on live export ship

props.synopsis: A federal inquiry into the government's plan to ban the live export of sheep from Western Australia backs the bill in its initial report handed down on Friday and calls for more funding for the industry.

title.children: Calls for Senate intervention into live export ban after claims government 'stacked' inquiry

image.altText: A young mother hugging her young son

props.synopsis: The parents of a four-year-old boy are furious he was removed from his long-time early learning centre after being diagnosed with epilepsy. Advocates say it's not an isolated incident.

title.children: 'It's constant torture': Heartbreak as 4yo excluded from kindergarten after epilepsy diagnosis

image.altText: Young smiling woman with long dark hair pulled back, holding a baby, whose face is blurred. both wearing brown, mustard clothes

props.synopsis: The opening day of a murder trial in the Riverina has heard Robert and Anne Geeves allegedly killed a teenager living on-and-off with them as part of a plot to gain custody of her five-month-old son.

title.children: Court told couple killed teen with intellectual disability because they 'wanted' her baby boy

image.altText: A man riding a bike in heat.

props.synopsis: Record temperatures in recent days are causing hundreds of deaths across Asia, Europe and America, as scientists warn climate change is fuelling more extreme temperature peaks.

title.children: Hundreds killed as extreme heat grips Northern Hemisphere

image.altText: Cherie Sibosado walks in NAIDOC event in Broome.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of people participate in a reconciliation walk marking the start of NAIDOC Week and share their pride in Indigenous culture in the Kimberley.

title.children: Resilience and representation key themes in Broome's reconciliation walk to start NAIDOC Week in the Kimberley

image.altText: A golfer looks over her shoulder and raises a hand to the crowd after holing a putt at a major tournament.

props.synopsis: Retiring US star Lexi Thompson has continued her resurgence to claim the first-round lead at the Women's PGA Championship, with world number one Nelly Korda lurking.

title.children: Retiring Lexi Thompson fires up to lead the Women's PGA Championship, Hannah Green leads Aussies

image.altText: A leech stretches out from a leaf

props.synopsis: New video taken on the jungle floor in Madagascar may finally provide an answer to a mystery — the first "concrete" evidence of leeches jumping.

title.children: 'A graceful jump' and a 'hard landing': Video captures first evidence of leeches jumping

image.altText: An overhead shot of a large crowd of pilgrims wearing white. There is a mosque building to the left.

props.synopsis: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade confirms an Australian is among the hundreds to die completing the Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.

title.children: Australian among hundreds dead in Saudi Arabia on Hajj pilgrimage

image.altText: A close up of Rishi Sunak making a speech and gesturing with his left hand

props.synopsis: Rishi Sunak's campaign to hold onto government has gone from bad to worse, as multiple figures within his orbit become embroiled in a rapidly escalating scandal.

title.children: 'Incredibly angry': What to know about the UK's insider gambling scandal

image.altText: seven-network-journalist-robert-ovadia delivers the news as he looks at the camera

props.synopsis: In a statement, Sydney-based crime reporter Robert Ovadia tells the ABC he had been fired after 23 years with the network.

title.children: Seven reporter Robert Ovadia 'sacked' following allegations of inappropriate behaviour

image.altText: A man with a yellow checkered shirt walks outside of court surrounded by female journalists holding microphones.

props.synopsis: Terminally ill 'bicycle bandit' Kym Allen Parsons will have his sentencing fast-tracked before his imminent death, and will seek access to voluntary assisted dying laws, a court hears.

title.children: Terminally ill 'bicycle bandit' to be sentenced urgently, before using voluntary assisted dying laws

image.altText: A real estate agency on left and a man with crossed arms on right.

props.synopsis: The ABC has spoken to 10 people about their experiences with property agent Ballarat Real Estate, alleging unethical and improper conduct, and potential breaches of the law.

title.children: Former clients engage Consumer Affairs after 'heartbreaking' conduct of Ballarat Real Estate

image.altText: Amy Scott wearing a police uniform in front of microphones, in front of Premier, Police Commissioner and Police Minister

props.synopsis: Inspector Amy Scott, the police officer who stopped Bondi Junction attacker Joel Cauchi, is recognised with a valour award and labelled a hero at a ceremony in Goulburn.

title.children: Police officer who stopped Westfield Bondi attacker honoured with valour award for 'exceptional bravery'

image.altText: Large crowds of nude people running into the water with red caps on.

props.synopsis: From nude swim loyalists to first-timers, a record 3,000 people drop their kit and take the plunge into the River Derwent in Hobart to mark the winter solstice.

title.children: 'A little different when the bathers are off': Hobart embraces record number for solstice nude swim

image.altText: Anthony Albanese wears a dark suit, smiles, and shakes hands with Li Qiang who is in a black suit

props.synopsis: Now a few more details about what was (and wasn't) said behind closed doors are starting to emerge, bit by bit.

title.children: Chinese premier's visit to Australia wasn't just 'panda diplomacy,' sources say, as the PM didn't concede ground on core issues

image.altText: Natalie Frahm, the woman killed by an alleged shooter in South Mackay.

props.synopsis: A quiet cul-de-sac in Mackay was the scene of a shooting this week that claimed the life of Natalie Frahm — and police still don't know why.

title.children: Natalie Frahm had only lived in the quiet South Mackay cul-de-sac a short time before suffering a 'violent death'

image.altText: An older man with a beard wearing a suit next to another man in a grey jumper.

props.synopsis: Kiefer Sutherland describes his father — who appeared in nearly 200 films and series over five decades — as "one of the most important actors in the history of film".

title.children: Donald Sutherland, the actor whose career spanned from the M*A*S*H film to Hunger Games, dies at 88

image.altText: A yellow truck on red dirt

props.synopsis: With nearly half of Australia's mining tyre waste generated in WA's Pilbara region, the focus is turning to how they can be recycled locally.

title.children: 'A dramatic change of heart': Miners realise 44,000 tonnes of tyre waste must be properly managed, recyclers say

image.altText: A composite of two images. Left, a picture of Charli in a white t-shirt with her black hair abound; Right, the Brat cover.

props.synopsis: Our take on the zeitgeist-dominating Brat, as well as new records from modern hip-hop greats and a couple of emerging Australian artists.

title.children: Seeing a lime green square everywhere? Here's why you should listen to the album behind the meme

image.altText: Composite of Peter Dutton, a man holding binoculars and a fish mouth with fangs.

props.synopsis: Think you've been paying attention to the news this week? It's time to put yourself to the test.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Peter Dutton's nuclear snack, an irreverent war film, and a freaky-looking fish

image.altText: Joe Biden speaks into a microphone, which he holds in one hand. He is holding up the other hand.

props.synopsis: If you're on social media, you might have come across a couple of viral videos this week, neither of which casts the US president in a flattering light. It's prompted the White House to fight back.

title.children: After an unflattering video of Biden went viral, the White House fought back

image.altText: Callum and Jake smiling and holding a dog.

props.synopsis: The identity of the fourth body found in the well where the brothers and their American companion were found has also been identified.

title.children: Fourth person arrested in relation to Perth brothers killed on surfing trip in Mexico

image.altText: Pat Cummins holds his arms in the air in celebration

props.synopsis: A Pat Cummins hat-trick and half-century to David Warner guides Australia to a 28-run victory via the DLS method over Bangladesh.

title.children: Pat Cummins takes historic World Cup hat-trick as Australia claims rain-affected win over Bangladesh

image.altText: Press shot of Australian music industry figure Jessica Ducrou with backdrop of Splendour In The Grass festival at night

props.synopsis: The co-founder of iconic music festival Splendour In The Grass and co-CEO of the influential Secret Sounds group, Jessica Ducrou has announced her departure from the company she helped create eight years ago.

title.children: 'What a wild ride': Splendour in the Grass co-founder exits company she helped create

image.altText: A woman in a blue top blowing her nose using a tissue

props.synopsis: It's not an extraordinary year in terms of the flu or RSV "in isolation", but this year's winter season is unusual because there are many things circulating together.

title.children: Between the flu, COVID and RSV, we have 'so many things circulating simultaneously'. Here's what the data says

image.altText: Albanese is seen through the window of a manufacturing facility, production line equipment in the foreground.

props.synopsis: The government knows it can't compete with China to make cheaper solar panels. But it's placing a billion-dollar bet that it can outcompete the manufacturing giant on technology to transform Australia's tiny solar industry.

title.children: Australia is placing a billion-dollar bet on making solar panels. It's exciting some, and alarming others
